Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 01:42PM Tazzy wrote: Ladies, just wanted to check in after surgery (1.30pm PST). I've just skimmed over the posts but want to say to all the surgeries coming... really we worry for absolutely nothing... I mean that - yes it is sore of course it is - but we have great pain meds so use them.   I didn't sleep well, but every time the pain woke me they gave me a morphine shot so I could doze a bit more.   The SNB I will not lie, hurts like a bitch for seconds then its over.   Even the mental side of it all... I even looked at the wound this morning when my BS was checking it out to discharge me... and you know what?  All I could think was "its OK... the cancer is gone its out of me".  I get the path report in about 10 days - 2 weeks and as BS is away my family doc will go over it with me for the margins.    BS said today that he was extremely happy with how things went - so that makes me happy. Even the drains aint that bad.   For those with surgeries coming up, I know you will worry, but please try not to too much, look on it as just a step closer to being cancer free. Well I am off for a nap now and typing really does make the arm ache. Damiana, SecretAgent...hope you are doing as well as I am. To all with surgeries looming - we'll be there with you in your pockets holding your hands. Positive healing vibes us all.

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2012 01:45PM Tazzy wrote: Drain free.... wooo hooo - oh it feels so good I can tell you.  And really didn't hurt... just a weird sensation, although I took 2 t3's before I went. HMP... I didn't do too badly on chemo really.   As my signature notes I was on  the combination of Adriamycin & Cytoxan.   After about 6 hours of it being administered I just felt blerh... that's the only way I can describe it.   Achey feeling like the flu and just feeling crap.   But it only lasted for me about 4 days... then I was back to having 2 weeks of doing OK before the next lot.   I brushed my teeth aftermost meals and rinsed out with baking soda (1 tsp baking soda to just under a cup of warm water)... never suffered mouth sores during all chemo.  I did get that horrible crappy metallic taste where most foods tasted like they were out of a bubbling mud pool, but that could be the adriamycin.   Taxotere hurt me more - or it could have been the neupogen/neuelsta shots.    since I have finished treatment, I have read on these boards that Claritin works wonders in helping with the bone pain.   My emotions were closer to the surface as well.   For taxotere make sure you are given ice gloves for hands and feet...this really helps with the neuropathy... if where you go dont provide them.. take bags of peas or something. When you are feeling crap and not sure if you want to do it anymore... .keep focused on the fact that chemo works... shrunk my tumour from 8+cm to 1.5cm.   Its hard but it is doable.   Oh! and keep a daily journal of how you feel and take it with you to each appt with your MO... really helps them and you too... you can see it does pass.  Hang in there sister... we're here for you and can hold your hand through the worse... you are not alone.    Ask any other questions you may have or fears you have - share them.

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2012 11:32AM Tazzy wrote: Calling all ladies, calling all ladies.   Would like to share a story with you and just wonder if there is anyone out there who knows the best people to contact regarding this issue:  Didn't know what other forum to post this on so chose this one (plus one other I post on). cutting a long story short: My parents (both 78 years young) live in the UK.  They contacted a company on the internet called Just Flowers to have a 'surprise' bouquet of flowers to be delivered to my home on Saturday August 4 when I returned from hospital after my mx.   On the Monday my Mum had to ask me if they had been delivered as I hadn't mentioned them.   No delivery here I said.  she called and they said that they would attempt to deliver on Tuesday as the original florist didn't have the correct product she had ordered.  Tuesday arrived, still no flowers, but an email to my Mum asking for a further $20 - on top of the $80 they had taken from her account - so that they could go to ANOTHER florist to arrange delivery.  she has asked them to cancel the order - still no refund of her money yet. So ladies in the LA/California region... who would be the best people to contact to let them know of this disgraceful so called service.   I have emailed the LA chamber of commerce, but wondering who else I can contact to put the word out.   Thanks for any advice. And honestly, if they don’t like it, screw ‘em. So today I was being nuked at 8am and went to a workshop from 9-1 through work. An amazing employment lawyer was speaking about a new workplace health and safety bill on bullying.. anyway there were lots of managers who I haven’t seen since I was dx’d. So one manager, who has always been a touchy, feely type came up to me and said “I never knew you were so sick until a while ago, can I hug you’ ‘sure’ I said. Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2012 11:19AM Tazzy wrote: Hi Trinity - I had Adriamycin, Cytoxan and taxotere.  I will give you how I was on AC - taxol being similar to taxotere is not the same so will keep those thoughts to myself.   Someone will be along with some help for you on that. Adriamycin:  First things first.. and I sound like a broken record with this... drink plenty of fluids... I like water so that was easy for me.   Not sure if you have a port, I didn't but water keeps the veins open for any iv's.   Try and have a slow walk... even for 5 minutes, keeps the chemo moving and out your body.   I did not get diarrhea - I got constipation, but that may have been the anti-nausea drugs.  if that happens, take stool softeners a few days before chemo and after... you will find out what works for you.  Also I incorporated more fibre.  to keep mouth sores at bay, what worked for me was a baking soda mouth rinse after meals.   Hair loss - as soon as I knew I was doing chemo I got my hair cut really short.  As soon as it started coming out... I got it buzzed at the cancer agency - put me back in control.  Also it hurts, you will feel your scalp getting tender, that goes once its gone.   Crappy metallic taste in my mouth - everything tasted like a mud pool.. .except for some reason red apples - so I ate lots of them.  Cant say I really lost my appetite even with that.. darn it.   Oh! and your pee will be pink for approx 24 hours afterwards... I was so happy someone told me about that one... would've scared the crap outa me.   Felt just blerh, no energy for about 7-9 days after... then would start feeling better again.  Cytoxan:  Hair was already gone so that didn't bother me.  I did lose my brows and lashes, but they are growing back quite thick now - June 22 was last chemo for me.   Really for me the biggest piss off on this was my nails became very weak and brittle, even though I wore cold gloves.  I cut my nails very short.  I had such lovely long nails before... even these are growing back now. I was fortunate that I never had any nausea.   Take all the meds they prescribe even if you think you dont need them.    Keep a daily diary of how you feel - I took this with me to every appt. with my onc before infusion.  You'd be surprised how you forget.   Oh and then there's chemo brain... really !!  Listen to your body Trinity... if it needs to rest, rest.   Not sure when you are starting - but let us know, wear big pockets so we can jump in with you. Remember they always give you ALL  the worst case scenario SE's - we are all different and dont get all of them.   I am sure there will be some other great advice coming your way.  And ask any questions you have. (((hugs))) and remember they are doing this FOR you not TO you

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2012 10:18AM Tazzy wrote: Because of the type of bc I had (high % for bone mets) I was offered a trial for Denosumab.  This as been on the market for about 20 years as an aide for people with osteoporosis.  Through their research they are finding (or hope to) that women dx'd with bc such as mine, Denosumab may actually keep bone mets/cancer at bay.  It is a blind trial so we dont know if we are receiving the drug or placebo... but either way it was a no brainer for me to do it.  The only way they will unblind us is if it proves to work.  I have the shot every 3 months for the next 5 years, which means my blood/urine is checked out, I see a clinical trial nurse and my MO every 3 months.  Also every year I am given a bone/CT scan and MRI, plus of course a mammo on my left boob.   Although only in the trial for 5 years, I am checked and given these scans for the next 10 years.   How could I say no ??

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2012 08:17AM Tazzy wrote: Morning Ladies, Christina: I met with my Nurse Navigator yesterday, Janet - she's an absolute sweetheart. She said not to splash out money on the medical camisoles for postop - they are expensive and not covered on benefits (least on mine). She suggested getting old or buying cheap tee's, cutting the arms out and wearing them and then pinning the drains - like she said, we are likely only going to need these for 2 weeks at most, so didn't see the value of buying the cami's. Also she said to start the postop exercises now to help prevent lymphedema. I was given a pamphlet for these - here's the link - hope works http://www.cancer.ca/~/media/CCS/Canada%20wide/Files%20List/English%20files%20heading/Library%20PDFs%20-%20English/Exercises-after-breast-surgery_2011.ashx One of the ldies on this board said that for showering she read that a cotton belt or pantyhose tied around the waist worked to pin the drains to so they didn't hang and pull.  She said it worked for her.  Prior to getting out of the shower she squeezed out the excess water, dried herself, put the t-shirt back on, re-pinning the drains, hung the pantyhose over the shower to dry - ready for next  use. Take cotton button up front pj's to the hospital.   Told me not to worry about a bra to go home in - that makes sense.   Again, to go home in comfy clothes, and tops that button at the front.  Oh, she did mention that for the tees - put your surgery side arm in first - sounds like we have to be contortionists, but I'm sure we'll do fine as others have before us. Janet also said that I would likely find the drain under the arm more uncomfortable than the chest one.    She will be in touch with me soon regarding a workshop she holds for postop ladies.  I'll keep you posted. There is so much we need to find out eh?  And I intend doing lots more research soon   I I'm sure if we share all the info we find out, we'll feel like pros before long. In the meantime, if you have any specific questions, let me know and I will call her to ask and get answers for us.  Oh! and happy news, saw my MO yesterday and chemo has shrunk my tumour considerably - woo hoo... so its hard, but it works - take that cancer! picked on the wrong person here. Today I am going to meet a friend for lunch and shopping trip.  The sun is shining here.  I hope you are all managing to enjoy your days. damiana - sounds like you had a lot of fun at your wig party - and yes, putting fun into our crappy situations does make it better.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 03:21PM Tazzy wrote: Hi Mycelle64.  I am not waiting, but was diagnosed in January 2012 and thought I'd reply in the hope of giving you some comfort and support.  No point in telling you not to worry - that's part and parcel of this I'm afraid.   Everyone who has gone through this will tell you the waiting is the hardest part.  Once you know, either way, you can make a plan and move forward.    The biopsy itself shouldn't hurt you.... it's uncomfortable.  They freeze the area so you dont feel anything.  Its only when the freezing wears off it aches.  Also they gave me a small ice pack to put on the biopsy site to help with the bruising.   Sorry you had to find this site..... The ladies on here are the most amazing bunch of people you will meet.  Knowledgable, funny, experienced.   Plus its where you can really express your feelings to others who know exactly what you are going through and no one judges. Good luck for Thursday and let us know how you get on. Take care.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2012 09:07AM Tazzy wrote: I met with my RO today.  She's an absolute doll and has all the time in the world for me.  That makes so much difference eh? Well, until tomorrow when I meet with my BS, she couldn't confim if I would be having rads before surgery or after.   Anyway what she could tell me is this.  Rads will start approx 6 weeks after either chemo or surgery.. so lets say after chemo.  That will take me to end of July.  They will be for 6 weeks, 5 days per week.   She told me all about the side effects and I have a ton of reading to do and a dvd to watch.   She said that the rad therapists will go over with me what kind of bras etc I should get.   So really not much news - but I'll let you all know how tomorrow goes. Hope you all had great days that were pretty pain free.

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2012 03:38PM Tazzy wrote: I am on my 2nd to last Taxotere treatment.    The put frozen gloves on my hands 15 mins before treatment, changed every 15 mins during and left on fo 15 mins after.   When I went for Treatment #2 I asked why they didn't put frozen gloves/socks on my feet as I had lost the 2 nails on the little toes.  they didn't hafvfe an answer so put the frozen gloves on my feet... and so far I've lost no other nails.   The nail beds are very tender, but so far I have all of the nails.    No one has mentioned losing them after treeatment has finished ? Yikes !!

Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 05:34PM Tazzy wrote: Hi Alison, I have 3D mammograms... our local hospital has the machine (only one in our region) and also I am on clinical trials and they request I have 3D mammos. The radiologists can decifer so much easier the breast tissue, especially if they are dense - the boobs that is, not the docs   I was also informed that they can read the images better as they can be seen in layers.   That's what they told me anyhow.   May also result in less call backs.   I'd be happy I had a doctor who cared enough. Unfortunately Alison, we still have to go through the boob squishing process with 3D's. Sorry you had to find us here...  but please let us know how you get on. If anyone can add anything they'll be sure to drop in and let you know.  These ladies are incredibly knowledgable and will share all they can.
